questions.question: Choose the correct coordinating conjunction: "She was tired, _____ she kept working."
questions.explanation: "But" shows the contrast between being tired and continuing to work.

questions.question: Select the correct subordinating conjunction: "He didn’t go out _____ it was raining."
questions.explanation: "Because" provides the reason for not going out, which is the rain.

questions.question: "Because" is a coordinating conjunction.
questions.explanation: "Because" is a subordinating conjunction, not a coordinating one.

questions.question: "And" can be used to join two independent clauses.
questions.explanation: "And" is a coordinating conjunction used to connect two independent clauses.

questions.question: Which conjunction fits the sentence: "I’ll call you _____ I get home."
questions.explanation: "When" indicates the time at which the calling will happen.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "I stayed home _____ it was raining."
questions.explanation: "Because" gives the reason for staying home.

questions.question: Fill in the blank with the appropriate conjunction: "He studies hard, _____ he always gets good grades."
questions.explanation: "So" shows the result of studying hard, which is getting good grades.

questions.question: Choose the correct subordinating conjunction: "_____ you finish your homework, you can go out to play."
questions.explanation: "If" introduces a condition that must be met before going out to play.

questions.question: Choose the right coordinating conjunction: "You can have tea _____ coffee."
questions.explanation: "Or" offers a choice between tea and coffee.

questions.question: Select the appropriate conjunction: "She sings _____ she plays the piano."
questions.explanation: "And" adds an activity that she performs.

questions.question: Which conjunction fits the sentence: "I will wait here _____ you come back."
questions.explanation: "Until" shows the duration for which the waiting will occur.

questions.question: Fill in the blank with the right conjunction: "He missed the bus, _____ he walked to school."
questions.explanation: "So" indicates the result of missing the bus, which is walking to school.

questions.question: Identify the subordinating conjunction in the sentence: "She couldn't attend the party because she had to work late."
questions.explanation: "Because" is the subordinating conjunction introducing the dependent clause "because she had to work late," which provides the reason for the independent clause "She couldn't attend the party."

questions.question: Which of the following is a coordinating conjunction?
questions.explanation: "Yet" is a coordinating conjunction used to introduce a contrast or unexpected situation.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a coordinating conjunction?
questions.explanation: "Before" is not a coordinating conjunction. It is a subordinating conjunction used to introduce a dependent clause that provides information about time or sequence.

questions.question: Which of the following is a coordinating conjunction?
questions.explanation: "Nor" is a coordinating conjunction used to introduce a negative alternative or contrast between two elements or clauses.

questions.question: Identify the subordinating conjunction in the sentence: "She decided to stay home because she was feeling unwell."
questions.explanation: "Because" is the subordinating conjunction introducing the dependent clause "because she was feeling unwell," which provides the reason for the independent clause "She decided to stay home."

questions.question: Which of the following is a subordinating conjunction?
questions.explanation: "Whenever" is a subordinating conjunction used to introduce a dependent clause that provides information about a specific time or condition.

questions.question: Identify the highlighted conjunction in the sentence: "I enjoy playing soccer, but I also like to swim."
questions.explanation: "But" is the coordinating conjunction joining the two independent clauses "I enjoy playing soccer" and "I also like to swim."

questions.question: Choose the sentence that correctly uses a subordinating conjunction.
options: I'll go to the party if you want to come along.
She was tired, although she had a good night's sleep.
We can go to the park or the beach, whichever you prefer.
I like to read books, and my brother prefers to watch movies.
questions.explanation: The subordinating conjunction "if" is correctly used to introduce the dependent clause "you want to come along."

questions.question: She wanted to visit her friend, _____ she was too tired to drive.
questions.explanation: "Yet" is used to introduce a contrasting idea, similar to "but."
